questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: What is the recommended amount of vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

 

The recommended treatment for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia involves high-dose vitamin A supplementation to rapidly replenish depleted stores and prevent further ocular damage. The specific dosage regimen is:

 

  1. 2,00,000 IU of vitamin A administered immediately.
  2. 2,00,000 IU administered again 24 hours later.
  3. 2,00,000 IU administered again after 2 weeks.

 

This regimen is designed to quickly correct vitamin A deficiency and provide sustained support to prevent recurrence and promote healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suggested vitamin A dose for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia is 200,000 IU, administered promptly, then repeated with the same age-appropriate amount after 24 hours and again after a span of 2 weeks.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age: -

 

  • <6 months – 50,000 IU orally
  • 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally
  • above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally

questions.text: Which of these hormones have intracellular receptors? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyroxine

 

  • Thyroxine hormone act by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors.
  • All other hormones mentioned in the options bind to receptors on the cell membrane.
  • Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.
  • The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process.
  • Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine: Epinephrine binds to adrenergic receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon binds to glucagon receptors on the cell membrane, which are also G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Option D. Parathormone: Parathormone (PTH) binds to PTH receptors on the cell membrane, which are G protein-coupled receptors, and does not use intracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroxine acts by binding to intracellular nuclear receptors, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis. This distinguishes it from hormones like epinephrine, glucagon, and parathormone, which bind to receptors on the cell membrane.

choices.text: Triangle of death and circle of death
Triangle of doom and circle of death
Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally
Triangle of doom laterally and triangle of pain medially

questions.text: The Trapezoid of Disaster includes: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic hernia repair, the surgeon must navigate important anatomical landmarks in the inguinal region. The "Trapezoid of Disaster" contains two important triangles that require careful attention during mesh placement. The Triangle of Doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by the testicular vessels, containing the external iliac vessels and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve. The Triangle of Pain is located lateral to this, bounded medially by testicular vessels and laterally by the iliopubic tract, containing the femoral nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: "Triangle of death" is anatomically known as the triangle of “doom”.
  • Option B: "Triangle of doom and circle of death" do not form a trapezoid of disaster.
  • Option D: This reverses the correct orientation. The Triangle of Doom is medial and the Triangle of Pain is lateral, not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Triangle of Doom contains vital vascular structures (external iliac vessels) while the Triangle of Pain contains important nerves (femoral nerve, cutaneous nerves). Accurate identification of these anatomical landmarks is crucial to prevent iatrogenic injury during laparoscopic hernia repair.

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region. It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.

 

The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.

 

Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: A lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parietal lobe

 

A lesion in the parietal lobe can lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination. The parietal lobe is responsible for integrating sensory information from various modalities, including vision and touch, to create a unified perception of the body and its surroundings. It also plays a crucial role in spatial awareness and motor control.

 

In particular, the parietal lobe contains the somatosensory cortex, which is responsible for processing tactile information from the body. This information is used to create a map of the body in space, which is used to guide movement and hand-eye coordination. Damage to the parietal lobe can disrupt these processes, leading to deficits in hand-eye coordination and other motor functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal lobe: Primarily involved in motor control, decision-making, and problem-solving, but not specifically in integrating sensory information for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option C. Temporal lobe: Involved in auditory processing, memory, and language comprehension, not directly in hand-eye coordination.

 

Option D. Occipital lobe: Responsible for visual processing but does not integrate this with sensory-motor functions required for hand-eye coordination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parietal lobe is essential for hand-eye coordination due to its role in integrating sensory information and spatial awareness, guiding movements accurately in response to visual stimuli.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

 

Meissner's Corpuscles are responsible for discriminative touch.

 

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Touch receptor with great sensitivity

An elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type AB. myelinated sensory nerve fiber. Inside the capsulation are many branching terminal nerve filaments.

 

Present in the non-hairy parts of the skin and are particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas of the skin where one’s ability to discern spatial locations of touch sensations is highly developed.

 

These are responsible for-Two Point discrimination, Fine touch and Slow vibration

 

If the question asks - Best for 2 point discrimination/ best for Braille reading/ static 2 point discrimination - the answer is Merkel


If the question asks - Most common/ most abundant/ maximum on glabrous skin/ primary / dynamic 2 point discrimination - the answer is Meissners
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel Disc: Allows one to determine continuous touch of objects against the skin.

 

Option B. Ruffini End Organ: Responsible for temperature sensation.

 

Option C. Pacinian Corpuscle: Responsible for pressure and crude touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

 

Paracellular Transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as, calcium, magnesium, etc.

 

The sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the basolateral cell membrane maintains a low intracellular sodium concentration and a negative electrical potential in the cell.

 

The 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter in the luminal membrane transports these three ions from the tubular lumen into the cells, using the potential energy released by diffusion of sodium down an electrochemical gradient into the cells.

 

Sodium is also transported into the tubular cell by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport.

 

The positive charge (+8 mV) due to slight back leak of potassium ions into the lumen of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid forces cations such as Mg++ and Ca++ to diffuse from the lumen to the interstitial fluid via the paracellular pathway.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active: Incorrect. This involves direct use of ATP for ion transport, not the main mechanism for divalent ion resorption in the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Secondary Active: Incorrect. While secondary active transport is important for moving ions, it is not the primary mechanism for divalent ion resorption here.

 

Option D. Transcellular Transport: Incorrect. Transcellular transport involves movement through the cell, whereas divalent ion resorption primarily occurs via the paracellular pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is associated with which of the following procedures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Stoppa operation

 

Explanation:

            

The Stoppa operation is the open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair technique for complex inguinal hernias. This procedure involves placing a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space that covers the entire myopectineal orifice bilaterally. It's specifically designed for complex, recurrent, or bilateral inguinal hernias. The Stoppa approach provides excellent coverage of all potential hernia sites while avoiding direct contact with nerves in the inguinal canal, reducing the risk of chronic pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtenstein operation - Incorrect because the Lichtenstein repair is an onlay mesh technique where the prosthetic mesh is placed on top of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, not in the pre-peritoneal space. While it uses mesh, it employs a different anatomical approach and placement technique.

 

Option B. Shouldice operation - Incorrect because the Shouldice repair is a tissue-based herniorrhaphy technique that doesn't use mesh at all. It involves multiple layers of suturing of the native tissue (double breasting of conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament and halves of fascia transversalis) to create a 4-layer posterior wall repair.

 

Option D. Mac-Vay Operation - Incorrect because the McVay (Cooper ligament) repair is another tissue-based repair that doesn't utilize mesh. This technique involves suturing the conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) rather than to the inguinal ligament.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Stoppa operation is characterized by placement of a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space for complex inguinal hernias, covering bilateral myopectineal orifices simultaneously.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: All of the following nerves are involved in the movement of the eyeball except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), and is not involved in the movement of the eyeball.

 

The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain. It is not directly involved in controlling eye movements, but it is crucial for vision itself.

 

The nerves marked in the image are:

 

  • A- Optic nerve (II CN)
  • B- Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
  • C- Abducens nerve (VI CN)
  • D- Trochlear nerve (IV CN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls the majority of the eye's movements. It innervates several extraocular muscles responsible for moving the eye in various directions, including upward, downward, and medially. It also controls the pupil's constriction and the accommodation of the lens for focusing on near objects. It innervates all extraocular muscles except - lateral rectus and superior oblique.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye outward or laterally. It allows for abduction of the eye, helping to look away from the nose.

 

Option D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for depressing the eye and intorsion (rotation inward). It helps in downward and inward eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in this image: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ascaris lumbricoides

 

The roundworm, Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

 

They are large cylindrical worms with tapered ends

 

The anterior end is more pointed than the posterior.

 

They are pale pink or flesh colored when freshly passed in stools, but become white outside the body.

 

The mouth at the anterior end has three finely toothed lips, one dorsal and two ventrolateral

 

Habitat - Small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum).

 

Natural host – Man

 

Infective form – embryonated eggs containing infective rhabditiform larvae

 

Mode of transmission – feco-oral route

 

Disease caused by A. lumbricoides is called as ascariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercoralis: Causes strongyloidiasis, and the worms are much smaller and typically not as robust as those shown in the image.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Causes enterobiasis or pinworm infection. The worms are much smaller and thinner, typically only a few millimeters long.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection. The worms are also smaller and have a characteristic hook shape at one end.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ascaris lumbricoides is a large, cylindrical nematode parasite found in the human intestine, easily identifiable by its size, tapered ends, and characteristic pink to white color transition. The disease it causes, ascariasis, is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

choices.text: Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors
Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X

questions.text: What is the most suitable culture medium for Gram-negative coccobacilli isolated from a tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcer? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitale X

 

Explanation:

 

Chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X is the most suitable medium for culturing Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of chancroid. This Gram-negative coccobacillus presents with the clinical picture of tender, non-indurated, and irregular genital ulcers. H. ducreyi shows a characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" appearance on microscopy and requires special media for growth. Chocolate agar with isovitalex X  (provides essential nutrients for growth)  is specifically mentioned as one of the appropriate culture media for this fastidious organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thayer-Martin Medium - This medium is primarily used for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis from specimens that may contain mixed flora. While it's used for some Gram-negative diplococci, it's not the optimal medium for H. ducreyi which causes genital ulcers with the described characteristics.

 

Option B. Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors - While H. ducreyi does require X factor (hemin) for growth, simple blood agar with X and V factors is not sufficient. H. ducreyi is extremely fastidious and requires more specialized media such as chocolate agar with isovitalex X for optimal recovery. H. Influenza requires Blood agar supplemented with X and V factors for its growth. 

 

Option D. Tellurite blood agar - This medium is used primarily for isolating Corynebacterium diphtheriae, a Gram-positive bacillus. Tellurite is inhibitory to many organisms but allows C. diphtheriae to grow with characteristic black colonies. This medium is not suitable for the isolation of H. ducreyi from genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Haemophilus ducreyi, the cause of chancroid characterized by tender, non-indurated genital ulcers, is a highly fastidious Gram-negative coccobacillus that requires specialized media such as chocolate agar supplemented with isovitalex X for successful laboratory culture and diagnosis.

questions.text: The given instrument is used for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Low air velocity

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Kata thermometer. The Kata thermometer was traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air. This measurement is based on how quickly the thermometer cools down when exposed to moving air, which directly correlates to the cooling effect of the air. However, its modern application is primarily focused on assessing low air velocity. It measures the rate of heat loss in still air, helping to determine the movement and speed of low-velocity air in environments such as controlled climates or specific laboratory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air pollution: The Kata thermometer is not used to measure air pollution. Air pollution measurement typically involves devices that can detect particulate matter or specific pollutants, such as gas analyzers or particle counters.

 

Option B. Air humidity: Measuring air humidity is generally done using hygrometer. Hygrometers determine the amount of moisture in the air, which is unrelated to the cooling effect or air velocity measurement.

 

Option C. Cooling power of air: Although historically correct, this option is no longer the primary use of the Kata thermometer. The instrument was used in the past for this purpose, but it has evolved to mainly assess low air velocity, making this answer outdated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kata thermometer is primarily used today to assess low air velocity.

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

choices.text: Pleuropulmonary blastoma

questions.text: Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hodgkin's lymphoma

 

Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that works as an immune checkpoint inhibitor by blocking the interaction between PD-1 on the surface of T cell and its ligand present on the tumor cell. It is used in the treatment of Non-small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, Advanced melanoma and advanced head and neck cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Nivolumab is not typically used for the treatment of retinoblastoma, which is a rare type of eye cancer that usually develops in early childhood.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: This is a type of brain cancer more common in children. Nivolumab is not a standard treatment for medulloblastoma.

 

Option C. Pleuropulmonary blastoma: This is a rare type of cancer that starts in the lung or pleural cavity, mostly affecting children. Nivolumab is not indicated for this cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor used for the treatment of Hodgkin’s lymphoma, among other cancers such as non-small cell lung cancer, advanced melanoma, and advanced head and neck cancer. It works by blocking the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction, thereby enhancing the immune response against cancer cells.

 

Immune check point inhibitors

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

 

Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

 

Ammonium urate stones are composed of a combination of ammonia and uric acid. When laxatives are abused, they cause metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline environment can lead to the formation of ammonium urate stones, as ammonium is more soluble in alkaline urine than in acidic urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form when the urine is persistently acidic, which can occur in conditions like gout or diseases that cause rapid cell turnover like tumor lysis syndrome. A diet high in purines, certain types of medications, and some genetic factors can contribute to uric acid stone formation. However, these stones are not typically associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option C. Struvite: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, are associated with urinary tract infections caused by certain bacteria. These bacteria can produce urease, which splits urea in to ammonia, that makes the urine more alkaline, which can lead to struvite stone formation. They are not directly associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone. Factors that increase the urine concentration of these constituents can contribute to stone formation. The absorption of oxalate might increase with chronic diarrhea (a potential consequence of laxative abuse), which can contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones, however this is not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.
Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.
Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct: The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.

 

Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct: A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.

 

Option D. It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct: The pterion corresponds to the region of the anterolateral (or sphenoid) fontanelle in the fetal skull. This fontanelle usually closes a few months after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterion is the junction point of four bones in the skull: the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The term "pterion" comes from the Greek word "pteron," meaning "wing," because the pterion is located at the point where the sphenoid bone and the temporal bone form a wing-like shape. The pterion is located just above the zygomatic arch and anterior to the ear. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs underneath the pterion and is at risk of injury in cases of head trauma.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

questions.text: Identify the audiogram. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

The audiogram shows:

 

  • Both air and bone conduction curves are close together (no air-bone gap)
  • Normal hearing at lower frequencies (250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, 2000 Hz)
  • Sharp characteristic dip at 4000 Hz (4 kHz)
  • Bilateral involvement (shown in both red color for right ear and blue color for left ear)
  • This pattern is typically seen in factory workers exposed to loud noises

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: Shows conductive hearing loss with Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz (2 kHz), not 4000 Hz. Also has significant air-bone gap which is absent here.

Option C. Meniere's disease: Shows sensorineural hearing loss with up-sloping curve affecting low frequencies. Does not show characteristic dip at 4000 Hz.

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Shows a banana-shaped or trough pattern affecting middle frequencies, with poor speech discrimination. Does not show isolated 4000 Hz dip.

Educational Objective: 

 

Noise-induced hearing loss has a characteristic audiometric pattern with a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, typically bilateral and symmetrical.

 

  • Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve - Otosclerosis
  • Dip at 4000Hz - Noise induced hearing loss
  • Cookie bite audiogram - Congenital hearing loss mostly
  • Trough shaped audiogram - Acoustic neuroma
  • Up-sloping curve with SNHL - Meniere's disease (low frequencies involved)
  • Down-sloping curve with SNHL - Presycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis - age induced hearing loss. Treatment: hearing aid}.
  • High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

choices.text: 48 hours
70 hours
90 hours
120 hours

questions.text: The half-life of letrozole is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 48 hours

 

  • The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours.
  • Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor which is used in the treatment of ER +ve breast cancers in post-menopausal women.
  • It is also the DOC for treating infertility due to anovulation in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours. It is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of ER+ breast cancer in post-menopausal women and as the drug of choice for treating infertility due to anovulation in women with PCOS.

choices.text: Labile hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension
Treatment of resistant migraine
Resistant Parkinson's disease

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for treatment of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide (NO) has specific clinical applications, particularly in the field of pulmonary medicine. It is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, especially in certain acute settings. It works by selectively dilating the pulmonary vessels by increasing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), thereby reducing pulmonary artery pressure and improving oxygenation. Inhaled nitric oxide is particularly noted for its use in newborns with hypoxic respiratory failure associated with pulmonary hypertension. It can also be used in the acute management of pulmonary hypertension in adults during cardiac surgery or critical care settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labile Hypertension: Inhaled nitric oxide is not used for the treatment of labile hypertension. Hypertension is typically managed with systemic medications rather than inhaled agents.

 

Option C. Treatment of Resistant Migraine: Inhaled nitric oxide is not a standard treatment for migraines, whether typical or resistant. Migraine treatment usually involves a range of other pharmacological interventions.

 

Option D. Resistant Parkinson's Disease: There is no established role for inhaled nitric oxide in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson's disease management primarily involves medications that affect dopamine pathways.

 

Other uses of inhaled Nitric Oxide:

 

  • Neonatal Care: It is particularly valuable in the treatment of newborns with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) to improve oxygenation.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): While its benefits in ARDS in adults are still a subject of research and debate, it has been used for its pulmonary vasodilator effects in some critical care settings.
  • Cardiac Surgery: Inhaled NO can be used during cardiac surgery to control pulmonary artery pressures.
  • Lung Transplantation: It may be used to reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve graft function immediately after transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in acute settings to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve oxygenation. It is not used for labile hypertension, migraines, or Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the standard agar recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using sensitivity discs? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Mueller Hinton Agar

 

Explanation:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the standard medium recommended for antibiotic susceptibility testing using the disc diffusion method. It provides consistent results due to its well-defined composition and is specifically designed for this purpose. For fastidious organisms, Mueller Hinton Blood Agar may be used as a modification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PLET Agar - This is not a standard medium for antibiotic susceptibility testing. PLET agar is a selective medium used for isolating specific bacteria Like Bacillus anthracis , not for determining their antibiotic sensitivity patterns.

 

Option B. Castañeda Agar - This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of Brucella species or fungus from blood cultures in a biphasic format (solid and liquid phases in the same container). It is not designed or standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing.

 

Option D. Cetrimide Agar - This is a selective medium used for the isolation and identification of Pseudomonas species, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Its composition is not standardized for antibiotic susceptibility testing, and the cetrimide component would interfere with accurate antimicrobial testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mueller Hinton Agar is the internationally accepted standard medium for antimicrobial susceptibility testing by the disc diffusion method due to its reproducibility, low content of inhibitors, and support of growth for most non-fastidious pathogens of clinical significance.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 154/94 mm Hg; Heart Rate 72 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 32 breaths/minute. He also complains of breathlessness. Which of the following is the preferred drug for management of this patient? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin


Scorpion venom causes release of a large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals which can lead to hypertension, tachycardia, breathlessness due to pulmonary edema etc. These effects are counteracted by using Prazosin, which is a selective α1 blocker.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Metoprolol: This is a beta-blocker used primarily for managing hypertension, heart rate control, and other cardiovascular conditions. It is not typically used in the management of scorpion stings, as it doesn't directly address the pathophysiological effects of the venom.

 

Option B. Ivabradine: This drug is used to reduce heart rate in certain conditions such as chronic heart failure and angina. It is not indicated for treating symptoms of scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Frusemide: This is a diuretic, primarily used to treat conditions like hypertension and edema. It does not have a direct role in managing the effects of a scorpion sting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the preferred drug for managing the symptoms of a scorpion sting, as it counteracts the effects of catecholamines released due to the venom, providing relief from hypertension and pulmonary edema. Other drugs listed do not directly address the primary pathophysiological effects of a scorpion sting.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is not common to both B cells and T cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Class I MHC Expression


Explanation:


T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Selection During Development: Both undergo positive selection in the thymus for T cells and bone marrow for B cells to ensure they can recognize self-MHC molecules

 

Option C. Antigen-Specific Receptors - This IS common to both. T cells possess T cell receptors (TCR) while B cells have surface immunoglobulins, both serving as antigen recognition units.

 

Option D. All of the above - This is incorrect because options B and C represent features shared by both cell types.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

T cells express Class I MHC on their surface (to present antigens to CD8+ T cells), but B cells do not express Class I MHC. B cells are more involved in antibody production.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)
